values.description:
SDFormat has a convention of using -1 to represent positive infinity. If users of the DOM API are not careful and cognizant of this convention, it can result in confusing bugs that are hard to track down. My dartsim plugin was exhibiting subtle non-physical behavior after loading structures from SDF, because it had effort and velocity limits of \+1 \(minimum\) and -1 \(maximum\).

This PR is a suggested tweak to the API behavior so that the API returns positive infinity instead of -1 to represent boundlessly positive values. Hopefully this might save other SDF users from long, confusing debugging sessions.

However, this does deviate from the exact convention of the SDF document specification, so I’d understand if this PR is declined.
values.title: [Suggestion] Return positive infinity instead of -1 for boundless positive values

summary.raw:
SDFormat has a convention of using -1 to represent positive infinity. If users of the DOM API are not careful and cognizant of this convention, it can result in confusing bugs that are hard to track down. My dartsim plugin was exhibiting subtle non-physical behavior after loading structures from SDF, because it had effort and velocity limits of \+1 \(minimum\) and -1 \(maximum\).

This PR is a suggested tweak to the API behavior so that the API returns positive infinity instead of -1 to represent boundlessly positive values. Hopefully this might save other SDF users from long, confusing debugging sessions.

However, this does deviate from the exact convention of the SDF document specification, so I’d understand if this PR is declined.
summary.html:
SDFormat has a convention of using -1 to represent positive infinity. If users of the DOM API are not careful and cognizant of this convention, it can result in confusing bugs that are hard to track down. My dartsim plugin was exhibiting subtle non-physical behavior after loading structures from SDF, because it had effort and velocity limits of +1 (minimum) and -1 (maximum).

This PR is a suggested tweak to the API behavior so that the API returns positive infinity instead of -1 to represent boundlessly positive values. Hopefully this might save other SDF users from long, confusing debugging sessions.

However, this does deviate from the exact convention of the SDF document specification, so I’d understand if this PR is declined.

values.description:
There is a bug in the parser that duplicates elements when unknown elements are parsed (originally reported as [drake issue 9222](https://github.com/RobotLocomotion/drake/issues/9222)). I reproduced this error by adding elements and expectations to `INTEGRATION_unknown` in a9f6e1b and 5ade669 (it fails with both those commits).

* a9f6e1b: Demonstrate bug that elements are duplicated when unknown elements are parsed

* 5ade669: add 2nd unknown element to test and expect exactly one copy of custom and unknown elements

I made a partial fix in a96183a that avoids duplicating known elements:

* a96183a: parser copyChildren: fix logic to avoid duplicating known elements

I fixed the duplication of multiple unknown elements in f73ac90 by moving the call to `copyChildren(...)` outside of the loop so that it only gets called one time.

* f73ac90: parser: Copy unknown elements outside the loop so it only happens one time
values.title: parser: don't duplicate elements when unknown elements are parsed

* 5ade669: add 2nd unknown element to test and expect exactly one copy of custom and unknown elements

I made a partial fix in a96183a that avoids duplicating known elements:

summary.html:
There is a bug in the parser that duplicates elements when unknown elements are parsed (originally reported as drake issue 9222). I reproduced this error by adding elements and expectations to INTEGRATION_unknown in a9f6e1b and 5ade669 (it fails with both those commits).

  • a9f6e1b: Demonstrate bug that elements are duplicated when unknown elements are parsed

  • 5ade669: add 2nd unknown element to test and expect exactly one copy of custom and unknown elements

I made a partial fix in a96183a that avoids duplicating known elements:

  • a96183a: parser copyChildren: fix logic to avoid duplicating known elements

I fixed the duplication of multiple unknown elements in f73ac90 by moving the call to copyChildren(...) outside of the loop so that it only gets called one time.

  • f73ac90: parser: Copy unknown elements outside the loop so it only happens one time

values.description: The `collision_detector` parameter added in pull request #440 is needed by an upstream gazebo pull request, so we should make a minor release. This bumps the minor version to 6.1.0, fixes some indentation in the changelog, adds 6.1.0 changelog entries, and alphabetizes some entries in the migration guide.

summary.html: The collision_detector parameter added in pull request #440 is needed by an upstream gazebo pull request, so we should make a minor release. This bumps the minor version to 6.1.0, fixes some indentation in the changelog, adds 6.1.0 changelog entries, and alphabetizes some entries in the migration guide.

values.description:
The goal is to parse `<frame>` elements and support computation of an element's pose in a given frame.  This pull request will be limited to models, links, collisions, and visuals. Additional pull requests will handle other elements. This work will eventually address issue #200.

What remains to be finished:

1. Need more tests, especially failure cases.
2. Update documentation.
3. Test and fix model renaming, which is done when a model is `<included>`.  A problem will arise if a model is renamed, but a frame inside the model refers to the original model name.

I should also mention that I'm not happy with the structure of the code. In particular how the frame graph class is passed around between objects. A more elegant solution will likely require a fairly major restructuring. Ideas are welcome.
values.title: Pose dom

summary.raw:
The goal is to parse `<frame>` elements and support computation of an element's pose in a given frame.  This pull request will be limited to models, links, collisions, and visuals. Additional pull requests will handle other elements. This work will eventually address issue #200.

What remains to be finished:

1. Need more tests, especially failure cases.
2. Update documentation.
3. Test and fix model renaming, which is done when a model is `<included>`.  A problem will arise if a model is renamed, but a frame inside the model refers to the original model name.

I should also mention that I'm not happy with the structure of the code. In particular how the frame graph class is passed around between objects. A more elegant solution will likely require a fairly major restructuring. Ideas are welcome.
summary.html:
The goal is to parse <frame> elements and support computation of an element's pose in a given frame. This pull request will be limited to models, links, collisions, and visuals. Additional pull requests will handle other elements. This work will eventually address issue #200.

What remains to be finished:

  1. Need more tests, especially failure cases.
  2. Update documentation.
  3. Test and fix model renaming, which is done when a model is <included>. A problem will arise if a model is renamed, but a frame inside the model refers to the original model name.

I should also mention that I'm not happy with the structure of the code. In particular how the frame graph class is passed around between objects. A more elegant solution will likely require a fairly major restructuring. Ideas are welcome.

values.description:
The pull request makes `<limit>` a required tag for `<axis2>`. This is currently the case for `<axis>` but not for `<axis2>`. This is counter-intuitive, but since the `<limit>` tag has defaults, making it required means the tag will be generated with default values if it's missing inside the parent tag.

As an example, before this PR, the following snippet would fail to load because a `<limit>` tag is missing in `<axis2>`.

```
...
<joint name="universal_demo" type="universal">
    <parent>universal_base</parent>
    <child>universal_shaft</child>   <axis>
      <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
    </axis>
    <axis2>
      <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
    </axis2>
</joint>
...
```

But it won't fail if I simply add an empty `<limit>` tag. Note that `<axis>` tag is still missing the `<limit>` tag. That's not a problem because `<limit>` is required under `<axis>`. 

```
...
<joint name="universal_demo" type="universal">
    <parent>universal_base</parent>
    <child>universal_shaft</child>
    <axis>
      <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
    </axis>
    <axis2>
      <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
      <limit></limit>
    </axis2>
</joint>
..

```
This pull request makes it so that the first example loads successfully.
values.title: [gz11] Make <limit> a required element for <axis2>

This is counter-intuitive, but since the `<limit>` tag has defaults, making it required means the tag will be generated with default values if it's missing inside the parent tag.

As an example, before this PR, the following snippet would fail to load because a `<limit>` tag is missing in `<axis2>`.

But it won't fail if I simply add an empty `<limit>` tag. Note that `<axis>` tag is still missing the `<limit>` tag. That's not a problem because `<limit>` is required under `<axis>`. 


This pull request makes it so that the first example loads successfully.
summary.html:
The pull request makes <limit> a required tag for <axis2>. This is currently the case for <axis> but not for <axis2>. This is counter-intuitive, but since the <limit> tag has defaults, making it required means the tag will be generated with default values if it's missing inside the parent tag.

As an example, before this PR, the following snippet would fail to load because a <limit> tag is missing in <axis2>.

...
<joint name="universal_demo" type="universal">
    <parent>universal_base</parent>
    <child>universal_shaft</child>   <axis>
      <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
    </axis>
    <axis2>
      <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
    </axis2>
</joint>
...

But it won't fail if I simply add an empty <limit> tag. Note that <axis> tag is still missing the <limit> tag. That's not a problem because <limit> is required under <axis>. 

...
<joint name="universal_demo" type="universal">
    <parent>universal_base</parent>
    <child>universal_shaft</child>
    <axis>
      <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
    </axis>
    <axis2>
      <xyz>1 0 0</xyz>
      <limit></limit>
    </axis2>
</joint>
..

This pull request makes it so that the first example loads successfully.

values.description: pull request #471 introduced `Joint::ThreadPitch` and `Joint::SetThreadPitch`, but the `thread_pitch` value wasn't read from the `sdf::Joint` element in `Joint::Load`.  This pull request fixes that and adds tests to cover more DOM functions in `sdf::Joint`
values.title: Store threadPitch from joint element

summary.raw: pull request #471 introduced `Joint::ThreadPitch` and `Joint::SetThreadPitch`, but the `thread_pitch` value wasn't read from the `sdf::Joint` element in `Joint::Load`.  This pull request fixes that and adds tests to cover more DOM functions in `sdf::Joint`
summary.html: pull request #471 introduced Joint::ThreadPitch and Joint::SetThreadPitch, but the thread_pitch value wasn't read from the sdf::Joint element in Joint::Load. This pull request fixes that and adds tests to cover more DOM functions in sdf::Joint

values.description:
Colcon is happiest when the cmake project name matches the `find_package` name (as mentioned in [this pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/685)). To support this, I added some backwards compatibility variables in the cmake config file that don't have the version number (ie `SDFormat_LIBRARIES`). I also had to adjust the `ign` to `cmd` file.

I also did a little bit of cmake cleanup:

* require cmake 3.10.2 (to match ign-cmake2) and use write_basic_package_version_file
* use `PROJECT_NAME_LOWER` instead of `sdformat${SDF_MAJOR_VERSION}`

UPDATE:

I merged in pull request #476 from @mxgrey  (thank you!) so that cmake targets are now exported. This should fix [ign-sensors issue 3](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/issues/3/sdformat8-include-directories-not-exported).
values.title: Change cmake project name to sdformat8, export cmake targets

summary.raw:
Colcon is happiest when the cmake project name matches the `find_package` name (as mentioned in [this pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/release-tools/pull-requests/685)). To support this, I added some backwards compatibility variables in the cmake config file that don't have the version number (ie `SDFormat_LIBRARIES`). I also had to adjust the `ign` to `cmd` file.

I also did a little bit of cmake cleanup:

* require cmake 3.10.2 (to match ign-cmake2) and use write_basic_package_version_file
* use `PROJECT_NAME_LOWER` instead of `sdformat${SDF_MAJOR_VERSION}`

UPDATE:

I merged in pull request #476 from @mxgrey  (thank you!) so that cmake targets are now exported. This should fix [ign-sensors issue 3](https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/issues/3/sdformat8-include-directories-not-exported).
summary.html:
Colcon is happiest when the cmake project name matches the find_package name (as mentioned in this pull request). To support this, I added some backwards compatibility variables in the cmake config file that don't have the version number (ie SDFormat_LIBRARIES). I also had to adjust the ign to cmd file.

I also did a little bit of cmake cleanup:

  • require cmake 3.10.2 (to match ign-cmake2) and use write_basic_package_version_file
  • use PROJECT_NAME_LOWER instead of sdformat${SDF_MAJOR_VERSION}

UPDATE:

I merged in pull request #476 from @mxgrey (thank you!) so that cmake targets are now exported. This should fix ign-sensors issue 3.

values.description:
When I added the major version number to the project name in pull request #475, I didn't realize it would break our release infrastructure. I've modified the cpack template to match what is done in the ignition packages, which was first proposed by @traversaro in the following pull request:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/63/fix-logic-of-installation-of-cmake/diff#chg-cmake/cpack_options.cmake.in

I will make the `8.0.0~pre3` prerelease from this branch.
values.title: Fix cpack now that project name has version number

summary.raw:
When I added the major version number to the project name in pull request #475, I didn't realize it would break our release infrastructure. I've modified the cpack template to match what is done in the ignition packages, which was first proposed by @traversaro in the following pull request:

* https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/63/fix-logic-of-installation-of-cmake/diff#chg-cmake/cpack_options.cmake.in

I will make the `8.0.0~pre3` prerelease from this branch.
summary.html:
When I added the major version number to the project name in pull request #475, I didn't realize it would break our release infrastructure. I've modified the cpack template to match what is done in the ignition packages, which was first proposed by @traversaro in the following pull request:

  • https://bitbucket.org/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/63/fix-logic-of-installation-of-cmake/diff#chg-cmake/cpack_options.cmake.in

I will make the 8.0.0~pre3 prerelease from this branch.

values.description:
The `geometry` parameter is used to set the sonar collision shape. Supported types are: `cone` \(default\) and `sphere`.

This pull request is related to [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3038/](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/3038).etry

values.description:
* assert size of errors before accessing elements to avoid seg-fault

* use negative mass to ensure that inertia is invalid, because zero mass is considered valid by math5

This was confusing to debug because math4 and math5 seem to have different definitions of valid inertia. The inertia is clearly invalid with negative mass.

[![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=sdformat-ci-default-xenial-amd64&build=119)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-default-xenial-amd64/119/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/sdformat-ci-default-xenial-amd64/119/

values.description: The sdformat includes the ign\_TEST.cc for sdf test build when ign-tools is installed. And ign\_TEST.cc uses popen & pclose  which has different function names in VC runtime libraries. [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-runtime-library/reference/popen-wpopen?view=vs-2017](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-runtime-library/reference/popen-wpopen?view=vs-2017)
values.title: [Windows] popen & pclose breaks the sdformat build when ign-tools in CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH

values.description: The size property of a `Plane` meaningful only for visualizing the `Plane`, i.e., when the `Plane` is used as a geometry for a `Visual` object. The `Plane` has infinite size when used as a geometry for a `Collision` object.

values.description:
Fix for the issue described in [#!/osrf/sdformat/issues/207/error-when-starting-ign-gazebo-if](#!/osrf/sdformat/issues/207/error-when-starting-ign-gazebo-if) and other potential errors due to the use of `std::stringstream`.

~~For uniforming the code, handling of double and float parameters have been switched to use~~ `std::stringstream` ~~as well.~~

There are two separated fixes:

* Introduce a private helper `StringStreamClassicLocale` that is just `std::stringstream` with `imbue(std::locale::classic()` called in the constructor. Use of this helper ensures that the parsing is independent from the C\+\+ global locale set via `std::locale::global()`.
* Move the `setlocale(LC_NUMERIC, "C");` from `Param::SetFromString` to `Param::ValueFromString`, so the case in which the `Param::ValueFromString` method was first called by the Param constructor is covered as well.

If necessary, it is possible to split this two fixes in two PRs.

I would have preferred to switch all conversions to C\+\+ facilities, removing the existing modifications of the global C locale, that are error-prone as any thread in the process could call `std::locale("")` between sdformat's `std::locale` call and the calls to `stod` and `stof`.

Unfortunately it turns out that removing `std::stod` is not trivial, as `stod` supports reading hexadecimal floating point numbers \([https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic\_string/stof](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/stof)\), that are not supported instead by `stringstream& operator>>(double& value);` . The situation on this is a bit confusing from a user point of view, because as far as I could find, sdformat specification does not specify which representations it supports for double and float numbers. XML-based formats typically stick to support only `xsd::double` \(see [https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#double](https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#double) and [https://github.com/ros/urdfdom\_headers/issues/41#issuecomment-345737929](https://github.com/ros/urdfdom_headers/issues/41#issuecomment-345737929)\) that **does not** support hexadecimal doubles, and indeed this is what is documented in the XML Schema generated by sdformat. Furthermore, hexadecimal double are only supported in scalar values, while when reading vectors the only representations supported are the one supported by `stringstream& operator>>(double& value);` . It probably make sense to discuss this in a separate issue.
values.title: Fix locale problems of std::stringstream and of Param::ValueFromString

summary.raw:
Fix for the issue described in [#!/osrf/sdformat/issues/207/error-when-starting-ign-gazebo-if](#!/osrf/sdformat/issues/207/error-when-starting-ign-gazebo-if) and other potential errors due to the use of `std::stringstream`.

~~For uniforming the code, handling of double and float parameters have been switched to use~~ `std::stringstream` ~~as well.~~

There are two separated fixes:

* Introduce a private helper `StringStreamClassicLocale` that is just `std::stringstream` with `imbue(std::locale::classic()` called in the constructor. Use of this helper ensures that the parsing is independent from the C\+\+ global locale set via `std::locale::global()`.
* Move the `setlocale(LC_NUMERIC, "C");` from `Param::SetFromString` to `Param::ValueFromString`, so the case in which the `Param::ValueFromString` method was first called by the Param constructor is covered as well.

If necessary, it is possible to split this two fixes in two PRs.

I would have preferred to switch all conversions to C\+\+ facilities, removing the existing modifications of the global C locale, that are error-prone as any thread in the process could call `std::locale("")` between sdformat's `std::locale` call and the calls to `stod` and `stof`.

Unfortunately it turns out that removing `std::stod` is not trivial, as `stod` supports reading hexadecimal floating point numbers \([https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic\_string/stof](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/stof)\), that are not supported instead by `stringstream& operator>>(double& value);` . The situation on this is a bit confusing from a user point of view, because as far as I could find, sdformat specification does not specify which representations it supports for double and float numbers. XML-based formats typically stick to support only `xsd::double` \(see [https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#double](https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#double) and [https://github.com/ros/urdfdom\_headers/issues/41#issuecomment-345737929](https://github.com/ros/urdfdom_headers/issues/41#issuecomment-345737929)\) that **does not** support hexadecimal doubles, and indeed this is what is documented in the XML Schema generated by sdformat. Furthermore, hexadecimal double are only supported in scalar values, while when reading vectors the only representations supported are the one supported by `stringstream& operator>>(double& value);` . It probably make sense to discuss this in a separate issue.
summary.html:
Fix for the issue described in #!/osrf/sdformat/issues/207/error-when-starting-ign-gazebo-if and other potential errors due to the use of std::stringstream.

For uniforming the code, handling of double and float parameters have been switched to use std::stringstream as well.

There are two separated fixes:

  • Introduce a private helper StringStreamClassicLocale that is just std::stringstream with imbue(std::locale::classic() called in the constructor. Use of this helper ensures that the parsing is independent from the C++ global locale set via std::locale::global().
  • Move the setlocale(LC_NUMERIC, "C"); from Param::SetFromString to Param::ValueFromString, so the case in which the Param::ValueFromString method was first called by the Param constructor is covered as well.

If necessary, it is possible to split this two fixes in two PRs.

I would have preferred to switch all conversions to C++ facilities, removing the existing modifications of the global C locale, that are error-prone as any thread in the process could call std::locale("") between sdformat's std::locale call and the calls to stod and stof.

Unfortunately it turns out that removing std::stod is not trivial, as stod supports reading hexadecimal floating point numbers (https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/stof), that are not supported instead by stringstream& operator>>(double& value); . The situation on this is a bit confusing from a user point of view, because as far as I could find, sdformat specification does not specify which representations it supports for double and float numbers. XML-based formats typically stick to support only xsd::double (see https://www.w3.org/TR/xmlschema-2/#double and https://github.com/ros/urdfdom_headers/issues/41#issuecomment-345737929) that does not support hexadecimal doubles, and indeed this is what is documented in the XML Schema generated by sdformat. Furthermore, hexadecimal double are only supported in scalar values, while when reading vectors the only representations supported are the one supported by stringstream& operator>>(double& value); . It probably make sense to discuss this in a separate issue.

values.description:
I have found the `gz sdf -p` command to be very useful, and it would be helpful to have it here in `sdformat`, especially when testing new pull requests, so I've added it here. I copied the approach for `ign sdf check` and added a test.

@nkoenig I didn't add anything to the `sdf/ign.hh` header file since I noticed the `cmdDescribe()` function was not present in that header file, so I wasn't sure that it was strictly necessary. What is the purpose of that header file? I suppose it could be useful for documentation and for checking API / ABI compatibility. If it's important, I can add the missing content to that file.
values.title: ign sdf print: add command similar to 'gz sdf -p' for converting and printing sdf files

summary.raw:
I have found the `gz sdf -p` command to be very useful, and it would be helpful to have it here in `sdformat`, especially when testing new pull requests, so I've added it here. I copied the approach for `ign sdf check` and added a test.

@nkoenig I didn't add anything to the `sdf/ign.hh` header file since I noticed the `cmdDescribe()` function was not present in that header file, so I wasn't sure that it was strictly necessary. What is the purpose of that header file? I suppose it could be useful for documentation and for checking API / ABI compatibility. If it's important, I can add the missing content to that file.
summary.html:
I have found the gz sdf -p command to be very useful, and it would be helpful to have it here in sdformat, especially when testing new pull requests, so I've added it here. I copied the approach for ign sdf check and added a test.

@nkoenig I didn't add anything to the sdf/ign.hh header file since I noticed the cmdDescribe() function was not present in that header file, so I wasn't sure that it was strictly necessary. What is the purpose of that header file? I suppose it could be useful for documentation and for checking API / ABI compatibility. If it's important, I can add the missing content to that file.

values.description:
It feels like a good time to merge the `gz11` branch back to default with the upcoming release of sdf7, which will coincide with the gazebo10 release.

Let me know if there is any major problem with this merge. This merge will mean that sdf7 will be the last release of sdf for both xenial and bionic.
values.title: Gz11 to default
